data.text: MyPlainvew.com May 29, 2011 OFF THEY Agriculture ........ 8A Business ............ 7A Classified ...... 9-12C Comics .............. 7B Lifestyles ........ 1-3C By KEVIN LEWIS Herald Editor One is short and one is tall, but the valedictorian and salutatorian of Plainview High School’s Class of 2011 offered much the same message to their classmates: It’s OK to mess up. “Yes, the future is scary, but don’t be afraid. It’s just life,” Hallie Wells, the 5-foot-4 valedictorian of the class of 304 graduates, said during Friday night’s commencement ceremony at Wayland Baptist University’s packed Hutcherson Center. “It’s a life where we mess up, fall short and shed lots of tears. But, who cares? It’s also a life fi lled with excitement, happiness and love.” Kacy Richburg, the 5-foot-10 class salutatorian, told her classmates to “enjoy this time in your life. Soak up every possible moment and live life to the fullest. Don’t be afraid to make mistakes, because the lessons we learn are what shape us into the people we become.” Wells made reference to her height and to being “vertically challenged. “When I was younger, being short really bothered me,” she said. “My parents always told me, ‘You might be small, but you have a big heart. It took some time, but I fi nally realized that my parents were right. I learned that instead of focusing on what you look like on the outside, it is important to let Memorial Day activities set By KEVIN LEWIS Herald Editor Memorial Day in Plainview will include a special cemetery ceremony followed by not one but two gatherings for veterans and the public. Monday’s 10 a.m. ceremony at the gazebo in Plainview Cem- MEMORIAL, Page 2A INDEX Obituaries ......... 4A Opinion ............. 6A Sr. Spotlight Spotlight ... 7-8C Sports ....1-2, .... 1-2, 8-10B TV Listings ...... ......3-6B 3-6B VOLUME 121, NUMBER 107 PET PE OF THE TH WEEK A popular pop feature in the Herald returns Page g 5 SUNDAY ONLINE POLL How many times are you watering your yard? myplainview.com SILVER STAR WINNER Joe Provence honored for commitment to the arts Page 1C PLAINVIEW HERALD GO! SEE MORE PHOTOS, VIDEO & THE COMPLETE ADDRESSES BY VALEDICTORIAN HALLIE WELLS & SALUTATORIAN KACY RICHBURG AT MYPLAINVIEW.COM your heart grow on the inside.” Wells made reference to Colossians 3:23 — “Whatever you do, work at it with all your heart, as working for the Lord, not for men.” She suggested being passionate for whatever path is taken and to “make your life an inspired journey. “Whether you’re big or small, let the heart inside of you shine so that you can reach your dreams. Now is the time for all of us to become the people we always dreamed of being. This isn’t the end of our story, but only the fi nale of a small chapter. “Make your life something worth remembering. Make yourself happy. Make a difference. The world is waiting.” Wells closed by referencing singer Taylor Swift and encourag- GRADUATION, Page 2A Kevin Lewis/Plainview Herald Plainview High School awarded diplomas to some 304 graduates on Friday at Wayland’s Hutcherson Center. At top, Jessica Rodriguez and Dallas Gutierrez share a hug; (above) Neissly Tapia sports fl owers and balloons as she poses for a photo with Annabelle Rivera; (at right) PHS teacher Leslie Richburg videos her daughter Kacy as she delivers her salutatorian address. Seated beside Leslie is valedictorian Hallie Wells. 75¢ Tuesday-Friday $1.75 Sunday Farmers planting & praying for rain By RICHARD PORTER Herald Agriculture Editor With the planting deadline for cotton just around the corner, area growers are getting their seed in the ground and praying for rain. Hale County producer Weldon Melton said the drought hasn’t changed many farmers’ minds this spring about their planting plans. “Most people are just staying with their regular program,” Melton said, adding that about 95 percent of the irrigated cotton around Plainview has been planted. Depending on where the fi eld is, the planting deadline for cotton on the High Plains ranges from May 31 in the northern Panhandle to mid- June south of Lubbock. In Hale County, the deadline is June 5, Wel- Gas thefts on the rise By JESSICA THORNTON Special Projects Writer Like the rest of the country, Plainview has seen gasoline prices increase the past few months, and that’s not the only thing going up. So are the number of people pumping fuel and not paying for it. According to Capt. Manuel Balderas of the Plainview Police Department, every time gas prices go up, so does the number of gas drive-offs. Most of the recent gas thefts have occurred at Allsup’s convenience stores. He pointed out that some convenience stores have pre-pay requirements in place to prevent theft, but some stores don’t, and so they’re more susceptible DRIVE-OFFS, Page 2A don said. Mary Jane Buerkle with Lubbock-based Plains Cotton Growers confi rmed that throughout the region growers are getting their seed planted.
